accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is restricted: Photocopying from the Review Board Records is prohibited.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. There may be a 48-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in the J. Walter Thompson Company Review Board Records have not been transferred to Duke University. For further information, see the section on copyright in the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], J. Walter Thompson Company. Review Board Records, John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising, and Marketing History, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Review Board Records were transferred to the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library from the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT) in 1987. Processing of this collection was supported in part by gifts from the J. Walter Thompson Company Fund and the John and Kelly Hartman Foundation.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Finding Aid Edited and Completed by: Katherine Rose, Completed March 1997

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Review Board, an advisory system began informally in 1942 as the Plans Board, when James Webb Young and Walter O'Meara headed the Creative Department. In 1956 JWT instituted the Review Board as a trans-departmental entity with written procedures and a Review Board Secretary.

In the years 1964 to 1969, Review Board functions were divided into a Plans Board, which reviewed the account team's recommended strategy (i.e., the basic proposition the advertising should made to consumers), and a Creative Review Board, which evaluated proposals for the implementation and execution of the advertising strategy.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Review Board Records, J. Walter Thompson Company's New York Office's primary mechanism for controlling the quality of its services, span the years 1947 and 1953-1976 (bulk 1956-1974). Senior-level creative, account, and management personnel composed the Review Board. It provided guidance to account teams, which were assigned to manage advertising for particular clients, and ensured that client campaigns reflected the cumulative wisdom of the Company's most experienced employees. Frequent changes in the Review Board system make a brief description of its operations impossible, but generally, five to eight creative, account, and management personnel comprised a Review Board for each advertising account. Clients' different brands might have a separate Review Board for each product. Individual Review Board members usually had responsibility for a dozen or more accounts. The procedures called for meetings at least once a year and every time account representatives considered a major campaign. The records consist of meeting minutes, correspondence, memoranda, and reports. Clients represented include Lever Brothers, Liggett and Myers, Scott Paper Company, Warner-Lambert, Standard Brands, Ford Motor Company, Chesebrough-Ponds, Eastman Kodak and a number of others.

The Procedures Series documents the organization and format of the Review Board over time. Also reflected is a widely held perception that the Review Board system was itself in need of some quality control. Confusion over time about the Board's scope and purpose led to numerous attempts at explaining and refining its procedures. The series is organized into the following subseries: Reports, Domestic Correspondence, International Correspondence, and Chronologies and Lists.
The Meetings Series documents the activities of the Review Board, focusing on advertising campaign strategies for JWT's clients. It forms the bulk of the collection.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.subject: Subject: Advertising agencies
Advertising -- Management
controlaccess.corpname: John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History

scopecontent.p: The Procedures Series contains reports, correspondence, and file lists relating to the Review Board's format, staff assignments, and meeting dates. It also contains correspondence, file lists, and a report relating to the semi-annual Account Summaries that account teams prepared for Review Board members.

Reports include documents that outline proper Review Board procedures and others that recommend changes in existing guidelines. This subseries also contains a 1967 report on format revisions for the semi-annual Account Summaries.

The Domestic Correspondence files contain correspondence and memoranda about procedural problems, member assignment notices, meeting schedules, and specifications for a remodeled meeting room. Also included are memoranda to account supervisors regarding overdue Account Summaries.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically with some overlapping dates.

scopecontent.p: International Correspondence includes information about the implementation of Review Board meetings in some of JWT's international offices, particularly those in Great Britain, Japan, and Brazil.

The Chronologies and Lists files contain two kinds of information. First, a chronological list records the dates of all Review Board meetings, the names of persons present, and brief, two or three word descriptions of the topic(s) discussed. This chronological record may be a useful resource for determining which client accounts were attracting the greatest attention from senior level personnel. Second, this subseries contains an annual list of the Account Summaries on file with the Review Board Secretary.

The Meetings Series contains minutes, Account Summaries, and memoranda pertaining to Review Board meetings. Meeting minutes and related materials (such as background memoranda and reports) comprise the bulk of the records. The minutes were recorded by the Review Board Secretary (or in some cases a Review Board member), and they generally include a list of Review Board members, a statement of the meeting's purpose, up-to-date marketing information, analysis of the advertising "proposition" (a capsule statement of what consumers should hope to gain from purchasing client's product), and final conclusions and recommendations. In some cases the writer records discussions verbatim, providing further insight into the personalities and groups processes involved (see files for Pan-American Airlines, 1959-1960; Chesebrough-Ponds, 1957-1959). There are no Review Board meetings minutes for 1966-1968.

Account Summaries often were submitted prior to Review Board meetings, allowing them to function like a background memorandum for particular meetings. Otherwise, they provided Review Board members with an accessible, systematic examination of the status of each account. The Account Summary format changed in 1967, but generally it contained the following information: financial marketing figures for the past five years, a summary of market conditions for the client's product, a summary of advertising (current objectives and expenditures), and a frank assessment of problems and prospects for the account.

Some folders in the Meeting Records Series are labeled "John Monsarrat" because they contain documents from his personal files. He was a member of some Review Boards, chairperson of several others, and the JWT executive responsible for the Review Board system in its entirety from 1960 to 1965. His files contain memoranda and meeting minutes that would otherwise be missing from the Review Board Records.
